clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Pulse Oximetry on Hospital Referral Acceptance in Children Under 5 With Severe Pneumonia
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Pulse Oximetry on Hospital Referral Acceptance in Children Under 5 With Severe Pneumonia in District Jamshoro - A Cluster Randomized Trial - (GAPPD Scale up Project)

brief_summary.textblock: The study assesses and compares the effect of 'pulse oximetry' (PO) used by Lady Health Workers (LHWs) at household level on increasing hospital referral acceptance rates in intervention clusters (district Jamshoro) for 2-59 months old children with severe pneumonia with the effect of LHWs using clinical signs alone in non-intervention clusters of the same district.

detailed_description.textblock:
Pneumonia accounts for an estimated 18% of under-5 mortality across the globe. Majority of these pneumonia-specific deaths occur in 15 countries, in which Pakistan ranks fifth. Failure to seek early care and delays in hospital referral are commonly acknowledged determinants of mortality in childhood pneumonia with a higher proportion reported from rural settings than urban. Acceptance rates of 'facilitated' hospital referral advice have been reported as low as 8-23% for sick young infants in peri-urban Karachi. They are even lower for non-facilitated referral in rural settings in children under five with severe pneumonia in rural settings.
Hypoxemia is an important sign of cardio-respiratory compromise in acutely ill children with a reported prevalence of 5.9%-58.9% in children aged 0-59 months from facilities and 16.1%-38.7% from community settings. Pulse oximetry (PO) is a rapid, portable, non-invasive and accurate method of measuring arterial hemoglobin oxygenation (Sp02), and has therefore been used in trial and clinical settings to detect hypoxemia. According to literature, mortality increases 4.3 times in children with pneumonia and hypoxemia than in those without hypoxemia.
The study hypothesizes that hypoxemia is a valuable sign of severe and very severe pneumonia in children 2-59 months and early identification at the community level followed by appropriate management with supplemental oxygen and antibiotics at the facility will improve acceptance of hospital referral and clinical outcomes
Study objectives
Primary Objectives:
To assess and compare the effect of 'pulse oximetry' (PO) used by LHWs at household level on increasing hospital referral acceptance rates in intervention clusters (district Jamshoro) for 2-59 months old children with severe pneumonia with the effect of LHWs using clinical signs alone in non-intervention clusters of the same district
Secondary Objectives:
Intervention Clusters (clinical signs plus PO at household level to capture severe pneumonia):
1. To determine referral pathways in intervention (PO) clusters in Jamshoro through a baseline survey among households and selected health facilities
2. To determine prevalence of severe pneumonia Â± hypoxemia in 2-59 month olds in intervention clusters in Jamshoro
3. To assess feasibility of deploying and using low cost oxygen systems (oxygen concentrators and/or low flow CPAP) at 1 referral health facility (DHQ Kotri) for intervention clusters in district Jamshoro
4. To assess effect of oxygen availability and delivery on clinical outcomes of children 2-59 months admitted with severe pneumonia at this facility and compare with clinical outcomes at home of those who refused admission.
Non-Intervention Clusters (clinical signs alone at household level to capture 'severe' pneumonia):
1. To determine referral pathways in non-intervention clusters in Jamshoro through a baseline survey among households and selected health facilities
2. To determine prevalence of severe pneumonia in 2-59 month olds in non-intervention clusters in Jamshoro
3. To assess feasibility of deploying and using low cost oxygen systems (oxygen concentrators and/or low flow CPAP) at 1 referral health facility (Sehwan Institute Hospital) in district Jamshoro
4. To assess effect of oxygen availability and delivery on clinical outcomes of children 2-59 months admitted with severe pneumonia at this facility and compare with clinical outcomes at home of those who refused admission
Sample size estimation:
Defining a cluster as (the catchment area of ) one Lady Health Worker (LHW), and assuming a power of 80% in detecting 15% increase in referral acceptance from a baseline 10% to 25% among 2-59 month old children with severe pneumonia (pneumonia prevalence at 2 week recall (MICS Sindh):7.5% (18% of which is assumed severe) a total of 116 clusters/LHWs will be selected from both intervention and control areas to capture 4640 children overall with severe pneumonia.
Study methods: An enhanced acute respiratory infections training module will be developed with training videos emphasizing classification of acute respiratory infections according to the new WHO algorithm, use of pulse oximeters to identify hypoxemia, identification of danger signs with addition of hypoxemia as a danger sign in intervention clusters, case management of pneumonia at home with oral amoxicillin and severe pneumonia with stat dose of antibiotic before referral to hospital. The faculty members of the Department of Pediatrics and Child Health at Aga Khan University Karachi, Pakistan will lead these training sessions with trainers of the LHW program.
Intervention (At the household Level):
All children aged 2-59 months with cough, fever, and difficult breathing or other unrelated symptoms during regular home visit, or whose mothers sought care for any reason at the nearby health house (active and passive surveillance), will be assessed for study eligibility by LHWs. After determination of eligibility (age 2-59 months, signs and symptoms of pneumonia) and informed consent by a legal guardian, LHWs will conduct the WHO classification of pneumonia (no pneumonia, pneumonia, severe pneumonia) and take a pulse oximetry reading using a handheld pulse oximeter (Masimo corporation CA) on all children with or without clinical signs and symptoms of pneumonia.
These pulse oximeters will be provided to the LHWs and the physicians at the basic health units (BHU) and rural health centers (RHC) in the intervention clusters (UCs Kotri City, Nago line, Son Wahar 2, AB Shoro, Son Wahar 1, HM Shoro, Son Wahar 3 in taluka Kotri). All the LHWs and staff at the BHU/RHC will be trained on the use, and maintenance of these pulse oximeters. Children with severe pneumonia with or without hypoxemia will be advised to go to hospital for antibiotics and oxygen, using the PO reading as a tool to convince parents. Name of a pre-designated health facility (DHQ Kotri) with available oxygen and study physician will be provided to all the LHWs so that follow up visits can be made to ensure the patient receives safe and recommended care at referral facility. Project staff will pretest and regularly monitor PO accuracy and quality of readings.
Hypoxemia will be defined as an arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) <92%. SpO2 measurement will be recorded after 1 minute of stable observation. If the SpO2 comes 92% or less, the child will first be assessed for nasal obstruction with readings repeated after applying nasal saline drops. If repeat reading shows hypoxemia, the child will be referred to nearest designated referral hospital and admitted for oxygen via nasal or nasopharyngeal route and intravenous antibiotics, as per recommendations. If the child with hypoxemia is diagnosed by the LHW, the subject will be referred to the designated referral health facility (RHC or district general hospital) through the usual channels if the child fulfills the criteria for admission i.e. SpO2 less than 92 or signs of severe pneumonia.
A small qualitative focused group discussion (LHWs, local families) may be planned midway to explore contexts behind decisions to accept or refuse hospital referral in both intervention and non-intervention clusters.
Control (At the household level):
Control clusters will also be chosen from Jamshoro district (UCs Sehwan 1 and 2, Channa, Jhangara, RHC Bhan, Talti, Bubak, Dall from Taluka Sehwan, UCs Laki and Sann/Aamri from Taluka Manjhand). All children identified to have clinical signs and symptoms of severe pneumonia in the community through LHWs using clinical signs alone at the household level and/or at the BHU/DHQ by the LHW/Physician using examination skills in non-intervention clusters shall be advised referral to hospital (Sehwan Institute Hospital) after a single stat dose of antibiotic.
At the referral facility (both intervention and control clusters):
All children identified to have severe pneumonia both in the intervention and control clusters in the community through PO done or clinical signs at the household by the LHW and/or at the referral facility by the LHW/Physician in intervention clusters shall be referred to higher level of health care. A referral hospital serving both the intervention and control clusters will have PO monitoring of all severe pneumonia children and delivery of oxygen through oxygen concentrators.
It would be of paramount importance to ensure proper equipment at the health facility with sustained supplies. In this regard preliminary meetings have been held with the EDOH Jamshoro and DG Health and their cooperation has been ensured. Emergency and pediatric staff at the facilities along with our study physician will also be trained on the management of severe severe pneumonia according to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines. Oxygen and supplies availability would also be ensured at the facilities so that children who are referred receive appropriate and timely care. The child would be assessed 2-3 days after receiving referral advice for acceptance or refusal and in either case for clinical outcomes. Even though it is ideal to provide sustainable oxygen systems to the two chosen referral public sector hospitals, the study does not provide oxygen and therefore aims to assess 'real-life' situations in public hospitals and their impact on severe pneumonia outcomes.
LHWs will have to be incentivized on basis of their contribution to the study activities.

intervention.description: In Interventions Clusters, LHWs will define 'severe' pneumonia as "2-59 months old children with hypoxemia (Sa02<92%) using Pulse Oximetry" and/or as "2-59 month old children with chest indrawing and 1/more danger sign"

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Children of 2-59 months age
2. Signs of severe pneumonia (clinical signs only in control clusters, clinical signs and/or hypoxemia in intervention clusters)
3. Written informed consent by legal guardian
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Residents of out of catchment areas
